page.title: 02ECOLOGY
page.content: The Inner Moray Firth is an important habitat for wildfowl and waders.Teal, mallard,widgeon and shelduck come south to the mudflats every winter for worms and small shellfish.Waders nest in the saltmarsh past the harbour all round to Longman Bay.The harbour extension and the dump have soiled it for them.Herring and greater black- backed gulls now swoop over the dump all year round.Guillemots,goosanders and mergansers feed on sprats in November and December.In summer fishing boats came in for them,and for the small herring called Kessocks. It was overfished.Now there is a fishery order against it.People sailing in the Firth have bottle nosed dolphins and porpoises nudging their boats.There are sea trout and flat fish for angling,but you mustn't poach the Queen's salmon.
